titleStmt.title: An inverse boundary value problem for the magnetic Schr√∂dinger operator with a bounded magnetic potential in a slab

analytic.title: An inverse boundary value problem for the magnetic Schr√∂dinger operator with a bounded magnetic potential in a slab

abstract.p: We study an inverse boundary value problem with partial data in an infinite slab in ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ, n‚â•3ùëõ3, for the magnetic Schr√∂dinger operator with an L‚àûsuperscriptùêø magnetic potential and an L‚àûsuperscriptùêø electric potential. We show that the magnetic field and the electric potential can be uniquely determined, when the Dirichlet and Neumann data are given on either different boundary hyperplanes or on the same boundary hyperplanes of the slab. This generalizes the result in [11], where the same uniqueness result was established when the magnetic potential is Lipschitz continuous. The proof is based on the complex geometric optics solutions constructed in [14], which are special solutions to the magnetic Schr√∂dinger equation with L‚àûsuperscriptùêø magnetic and electric potentials in a bounded domain.

div.head: INTRODUCTION AND STATEMENT OF RESULTS
div.p: In this paper we study an inverse boundary value problems with partial data for the magnetic Schr√∂dinger operator with bounded magnetic potential and bounded electric potential in an infinite slab.
A magnetic Schr√∂dinger operator with bounded magnetic potential and bounded electric potential is a differential operator of the form

In this paper we consider the inverse boundary value problem of determining the magnetic field d‚Å¢Aùëëùê¥ and the electric potential qùëû for only bounded Aùê¥ and qùëû. Our main results in this paper are the following two theorems. They generalize the results in [15], which were obtained when A=0ùê¥0, and the results in [11], which were obtained when A‚ààW1,‚àû‚Å¢(Œ£;‚ÑÇn)ùê¥superscriptùëä1Œ£superscript‚ÑÇùëõ is compactly supported. The first result concerns the case when the data and the measurements are on different boundary hyperplanes, while the second deals with the case when the data and the measurements are on the same boundary hyperplanes.

div.p: The proofs of Theorem 1.1 and Theorem 1.2 are based on the construction of a special kind of complex geometric optics (CGO) solutions which vanish on appropriate subsets of the boundary hyperplanes, through a reflection argument. The constructions of CGO solutions for the conductivity equation and the Schr√∂dinger equation go back to [23]. Constructing CGO solutions by using a reflection argument was initiated in [9]. It was applied to the inverse boundary value problem for the Schr√∂dinger operator in a slab in [15], and for the magnetic Sch√∂dinger operator in a slab in [11].

The geometry of an infinite slab shows up in modeling the propagation of acoustic waves in shallow oceans, see [1]. Various inverse problems in a slab have been studied by many authors. In [8, 21], inverse conductivity problems in a slab were studied; in [4], an inverse scattering problem for the Schr√∂dinger operator in a slab was considered.

Another closely related inverse problem for the magnetic Schr√∂dinger operator is the inverse boundary value problem in a bounded open subset Œ©Œ© of ‚Ñùnsuperscript‚Ñùùëõ, n‚â•3ùëõ3. In this problem one hopes to determine the magnetic field and the electric potential by measuring the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map on the boundary ‚àÇ‚Å°Œ©Œ©, under various regularity assumption on the magnetic potential Aùê¥ and the electric potential qùëû. In [22], this type of determination was established for W2,‚àûsuperscriptùëä2 magnetic potentials, which are small in a suitable sense, and L‚àûsuperscriptùêø electric potentials. In [16], the smallness condition was removed for C‚àûsuperscriptùê∂ magnetic and electric potentials. This uniqueness was extended to C1superscriptùê∂1 magnetic potentials in [25], to some less regularity but small potentials in [17], to Dini continuous magnetic potentials in [18], and recently to L‚àûsuperscriptùêø magnetic and electric potentials in [14].

In a bounded domain Œ©Œ©, one may also consider this inverse boundary value problem with partial boundary measurements. More precisely, let Œ≥1subscriptùõæ1 and Œ≥2subscriptùõæ2 be two open subsets of ‚àÇ‚Å°Œ©Œ©, and let the partial data measurements be ùí©A,q‚Å¢(f)|Œ≥2evaluated-atsubscriptùí©ùê¥ùëûùëìsubscriptùõæ2 for all fùëì with s‚Å¢u‚Å¢p‚Å¢p‚Å¢(f)‚äÇŒ≥1ùë†ùë¢ùëùùëùùëìsubscriptùõæ1. Determination of the magnetic potential and the electric potential from partial boundary measurements was proved in [5] when Œ≥1=‚àÇ‚Å°Œ©subscriptùõæ1Œ© and Œ≥2subscriptùõæ2 is possibly a very small subset. Under the assumption that A(1)=A(2)superscriptùê¥1superscriptùê¥2 and q(1)=q(2)superscriptùëû1superscriptùëû2 in a neighborhood of the boundary, it was proved in [2] when Œ≥1=‚àÇ‚Å°Œ©subscriptùõæ1Œ© and Œ≥2subscriptùõæ2 is arbitrary. This was generalized to arbitrary non-empty subsets Œ≥1,Œ≥2‚äÇ‚àÇ‚Å°Œ©subscriptùõæ1subscriptùõæ2Œ© in [11]. Logarithmic stability estimate for this problem was obtained in [2].

This paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we review the construction of CGO solutions in a bounded domain Œ©‚äÇ‚ÑùnŒ©superscript‚Ñùùëõ, n‚â•3ùëõ3, to the magnetic Schr√∂dinger equation with L‚àûsuperscriptùêø magnetic and electric potentials, following [14]. Section 3 contains the proof of Theorem 1.1, and is divided into three parts: Section 3.1 establishes an integral inequality of Green‚Äôs type for some special solutions of the magnetic Schr√∂dinger equation; Section 3.2 shows how to construct the desired partial data CGO solutions from the CGO solutions constructed in Section 2 through a reflection argument; In Section 3.3, we finish the proof of Theorem 1.1 by combining the result in Section 3.1 and 3.2. Section 4 demonstrates the proof of Theorem 1.2.

div.head: CGO SOLUTIONS
div.p: In this section, we recall how to construct CGO solutions for the mangetic Schr√∂dinger operator with a bounded magnetic potential on a bounded domain. For detailed construction we refer to [14]. This construction together with a reflection argument will allow us to construct the special partial data CGO solutions in the infinite slab Œ£Œ£.

div.head: Proof of Theorem 1.2
div.p: The proof of Theorem 1.2 is analogous to that of Theorem 1.1. We will derive an integral identity, construct some partial data CGO solutions, and finally derive the vanishing of the Fourier transform of some compactly supported distributions to conclude the uniqueness.

First, by a similar argument as in Section 3.1, we can obtain the identity (3.8) for all u1‚ààùí≤l2‚Å¢(Œ£‚à©B)subscriptùë¢1subscriptùí≤subscriptùëô2Œ£ùêµ and u2‚ààùí±l2‚Å¢(Œ£‚à©B)subscriptùë¢2subscriptùí±subscriptùëô2Œ£ùêµ.
